1 Topology Spaces and Continuous Function

This is a note for general topology. The main reference is Topology.

The note is written in Pandoc Markdown.

My GitHub repository for this note.

1.1 Basic Definition of Topology

::: {#def:Topology .definition} Definition 1.1 (topology). A topology on a set X\mathbb{X}X is a collection T\mathbb{T}T of subsets of X\mathbb{X}X having the following properties:

  • ∅\emptyset∅ and X\mathbb{X}X are in T\mathbb{T}T

  • The union of the elements of any sub collection of T\mathbb{T}T is in T\mathbb{T}T

  • The intersection of the elements of any finite sub collection of T\mathbb{T}T is in T\mathbb{T}T :::

::: {#def:TopologySpace .definition} Definition 1.2 (topology space). A topological space is a set X\mathbb{X}X for which a topology T\mathbb{T}T has been specified. :::

::: {#def:OpenSet .definition} Definition 1.3 (open set). A open set U\mathbb{U}U is a subset of X\mathbb{X}X that belongs to a topology T\mathbb{T}T of X\mathbb{X}X. :::

::: {#def:OpenSets .definition} Definition 1.4 (open sets). A topology can also be called a open sets :::

::: {#def:DiscreteTopology .definition} Definition 1.5 (discrete topology). The set of all subsets of a set X\mathbb{X}X formed a topology called discrete topology :::

::: {#def:TrivialTopology .definition} Definition 1.6 (trivial topology). The set consisting the set X\mathbb{X}X and ∅\emptyset∅ only formed a topology of X\mathbb{X}X called trivial topology :::

::: {#def:FiniteComplementTopology .definition} Definition 1.7 (finite complement topology). Let X\mathbb{X}X be a set. Let Tf\mathbb{T}_{\mathit{f}}Tf​ be the collection of all subsets U\mathbb{U}U of X\mathbb{X}X such that X−U\mathbb{X} - \mathbb{U}X−U either if a finite 1 of is all of X\mathbb{X}X. Then Tf\mathbb{T}_{\mathit{f}}Tf​ is a topology on X\mathbb{X}X, called the finite complement topology. :::

::: {#def:Comparable .definition} Definition 1.8 (finer, larger, strictly finer, strictly larger, coarser, smaller, strictly coarser, strictly smaller, comparable). Let T\mathbb{T}T and T′\mathbb{T'}T′ be two topology on a given set X\mathbb{X}X. If T\mathbb{T}T is a subset of T′\mathbb{T'}T′, we say that T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is finer or larger than T\mathbb{T}T. If T\mathbb{T}T is a proper subset of T′\mathbb{T'}T′, we say that T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is strictly finer or strictly larger than T\mathbb{T}T. We also say that T\mathbb{T}T is coarser or smaller or strictly coarser or strictly smaller than T′\mathbb{T'}T′. We say that T\mathbb{T}T and T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is comparable if either T\mathbb{T}T is a subset of T′\mathbb{T'}T′ or T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is a subset of T\mathbb{T}T. :::

1.2 Basis for a Topology

::: {#def:Basis .definition} Definition 1.9 (basis). If X\mathbb{X}X is a set, a basis for a topology on X\mathbb{X}X is a collection B\mathbb{B}B of subsets of X\mathbb{X}X (called basis elements) such that:

  • For each x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X, there is at least one basis element BBB containing xxx

  • If xxx belongs to the intersection of two basis elements B1B_{1}B1​ and B2B_{2}B2​, then there is another element x∈B3∈Bx \in B_{3} \in \mathbb{B}x∈B3​∈B such that B3⊆B1∩B2B_{3} \subseteq B_{1} \cap B_{2}B3​⊆B1​∩B2​ :::

::: {#def:TopologyGeneratedByBasis .definition} Definition 1.10 (topology generated by basis). Let B\mathbb{B}B be a basis on X\mathbb{X}X . Let U\mathbb{U}U be a set containing all subsets UUU of X\mathbb{X}X such that for each element x∈Ux \in Ux∈U, there is B∈BB \in \mathbb{B}B∈B that x∈B⊆Ux \in B \subseteq Ux∈B⊆U. Such U\mathbb{U}U formed a topology on X\mathbb{X}X , called topology T\mathbb{T}T generated by B\mathbb{B}B :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.1. Let X\mathbb{X}X be a set. Let B\mathbb{B}B be a basis for a topology T\mathbb{T}T on X\mathbb{X}X . Then T\mathbb{T}T equals to the set of all possible unions of elements of B\mathbb{B}B . :::

::: proof Proof. Let set U\mathbb{U}U be the set of all possible unions of elements of B\mathbb{B}B . For any U∈UU \in \mathbb{U}U∈U. U=∪BU = \cup BU=∪B 2 for some B∈BB \in \mathbb{B}B∈B. Thus, for every x∈Ux \in Ux∈U, there exist a B′∈BB' \in \mathbb{B}B′∈B that x∈B′⊆Ux \in B' \subseteq Ux∈B′⊆U. Thus, U∈TU \in \mathbb{T}U∈T.

Conversely, for any U∈TU \in \mathbb{T}U∈T. For any x∈Ux \in Ux∈U, let x∈Bx∈Ux \in B_{x} \in Ux∈Bx​∈U. Then, U=∪x∈UBxU = \cup_{x \in U}B_{x}U=∪x∈U​Bx​. Thus, U∈UU \in \mathbb{U}U∈U.

Therefore, U\mathbb{U}U equals to T\mathbb{T}T . ◻ :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.2. 3 Let X\mathbb{X}X be a topological space. Suppose that C\mathbb{C}C is a collection of open sets of X\mathbb{X}X such that for each open set UUU of X\mathbb{X}X and each x∈Ux \in Ux∈U, there is an element C∈CC \in \mathbb{C}C∈C such that x∈C⊆Cx \in C \subseteq Cx∈C⊆C. Then C\mathbb{C}C is a basis for the topology of X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.3. 4 Let B\mathbb{B}B and B′\mathbb{B'}B′ be basis for the topologies T\mathbb{T}T and T′\mathbb{T'}T′ , respectively, on X\mathbb{X}X . Then the following are equivalent:

  • T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is finer than T\mathbb{T}T

  • For each x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X and each basis element B∈BB \in \mathbb{B}B∈B containing X, there is a basis element B′∈B′B' \in \mathbb{B'}B′∈B′ such that x∈B′⊆Bx \in B' \subseteq Bx∈B′⊆B. :::

::: {#def:StandardTopologyOnTheRealLine .definition} Definition 1.11 (standard topology on the real line). Let be B={B∣B={x∣a<x<b},a<b,a∈R,b∈R}\mathbb{B} = \{ B | B = \{ x | a < x < b \}, a < b, a \in \mathbb{R}, b \in \mathbb{R} \}B={B∣B={x∣a<x<b},a<b,a∈R,b∈R}. B\mathbb{B}B formed a basis on real line. The topology generated by B\mathbb{B}B is called the standard topology on the real line 5 . :::

::: {#def:LowerLimitTopologyOnTheRealLine .definition} Definition 1.12 (lower limit topology on the real line). Let be B={B∣B={x∣a≤x<b},a<b,a∈R,b∈R}\mathbb{B} = \{ B | B = \{ x | a \le x < b \}, a < b, a \in \mathbb{R}, b \in \mathbb{R} \}B={B∣B={x∣a≤x<b},a<b,a∈R,b∈R}. B\mathbb{B}B formed a basis on real line. The topology generated by B\mathbb{B}B is called the lower limit topology on the real line. When R\mathbb{R}R is given this topology,we denote it by Rl\mathbb{R}_{l}Rl​. :::

::: {#def:KTopologyOnTheRealLine .definition} Definition 1.13 (K-topology on the real line). Let be B={B∣B={x∣a<x<b},a<b,a∈R,b∈R}\mathbb{B} = \{ B | B = \{ x | a < x < b \}, a < b, a \in \mathbb{R}, b \in \mathbb{R} \}B={B∣B={x∣a<x<b},a<b,a∈R,b∈R}. Let K={x∣x=1n,n∈Z+}K = \{ x | x = \frac{1}{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z_{+}} \}K={x∣x=n1​,n∈Z+​}. B∪{B−K∣B∈B}\mathbb{B} \cup \{ B - K | B \in \mathbb{B} \}B∪{B−K∣B∈B} formed a basis on real line. The topology generated by B\mathbb{B}B is called the K-topology on the real line. When R\mathbb{R}R is given this topology,we denote it by RK\mathbb{R_{K}}RK​. :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.4. 6 The topologies Rl\mathbb{R}_{l}Rl​ and RK\mathbb{R_{K}}RK​ is strictly finer than the standard topology on R\mathbb{R}R . :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.5. The topologies of Rl\mathbb{R}_{l}Rl​ and RK\mathbb{R_{K}}RK​ is not comparable. :::

::: proof Proof. Let Tl\mathbb{T}_{l}Tl​ and TK\mathbb{T_{K}}TK​ be topologies of Rl\mathbb{R}_{l}Rl​ and RK\mathbb{R_{K}}RK​ respectively. Let K={x∣x=1n,n∈Z+}K = \{ x | x = \frac{1}{n}, n \in \mathbb{Z_{+}} \}K={x∣x=n1​,n∈Z+​}.

We first proof that Tl\mathbb{T}_{l}Tl​ is not finer than TK\mathbb{T_{K}}TK​ . Let U={x∣−1<x<1}−K,x=0U = \{ x | -1 < x < 1 \} - K, x = 0U={x∣−1<x<1}−K,x=0. If there exist B={x∣a≤x<b}∈TlB = \{ x | a \le x < b \} \in \mathbb{T}_{l}B={x∣a≤x<b}∈Tl​ such that x∈B⊆Ux \in B \subseteq Ux∈B⊆U, then 0<b<10 < b < 10<b<1. Thus, there exist n∈Z+n \in \mathbb{Z_{+}}n∈Z+​ that 0<1n<b0 < \frac{1}{n} < b0<n1​<b. Thus BBB is not a subset of UUU.

Then we proof that TK\mathbb{T_{K}}TK​ is not finer than Tl\mathbb{T}_{l}Tl​. Let U′={x∣a′≤x<b′}U' = \{ x | a' \le x < b' \}U′={x∣a′≤x<b′}. If there exist B′={x∣a′′<x<b′′}or{x∣a′′<x<b′′}−KB' = \{ x | a'' < x < b'' \} or \{ x | a'' < x < b'' \} - KB′={x∣a′′<x<b′′}or{x∣a′′<x<b′′}−K such that a′∈B⊆U{a'} \in B \subseteq Ua′∈B⊆U. Thus a′′<a<b′′a'' < a < b''a′′<a<b′′. Thus there exist ccc that a′′<x<a,x∈B,x∉U′a'' < x < a, x \in B ,x \notin U'a′′<x<a,x∈B,x∈/U′. Thus B′⊈U′B' \nsubseteq U'B′⊈U′.

Thus the topologies of Rl\mathbb{R}_{l}Rl​ and RK\mathbb{R_{K}}RK​ is not comparable. ◻ :::

::: {#def:Subbasis .definition} Definition 1.14 (subbasis). A subbasis S\mathbb{S}S for a topology on X\mathbb{X}X is a collection of subsets of X\mathbb{X}X whose union equals X\mathbb{X}X . The topology generated by the subbasis S\mathbb{S}S is defined to be the collection T\mathbb{T}T 7 of all unions of finite intersections of elements of S\mathbb{S}S . :::

1.2.1 Exercise

  1. Show that if A\mathbb{A}A is a basis for a topology on X\mathbb{X}X , then the topology generated by A\mathbb{A}A equals the intersection of all topologies on X\mathbb{X}X that contain A\mathbb{A}A . Prove the same if A\mathbb{A}A is a subbasis.

    ::: proof Proof. As a subbasis is also a basis, we will directly prove the case of subbasis here.

    Let S={Tα}\mathbb{S} = \{ \mathbb{T}_{\alpha} \}S={Tα​} be set contain all the topologies that contain A\mathbb{A}A . Let T\mathbb{T}T be the topology that A\mathbb{A}A generated. Let T′=∩Tα\displaystyle \mathbb{T}' = \cap\mathbb{T}_{\alpha}T′=∩Tα​.8

    First, A⊆Tα\mathbb{A} \subseteq \mathbb{T}_{\alpha}A⊆Tα​. Thus, T⊆Tα\mathbb{T} \subseteq \mathbb{T}_{\alpha}T⊆Tα​. Thus, T⊆T′\mathbb{T} \subseteq \mathbb{T}'T⊆T′.

    Also, A⊆T\mathbb{A} \subseteq \mathbb{T}A⊆T. Thus, T∈S\mathbb{T} \in \mathbb{S}T∈S. Thus, T′⊆T\mathbb{T}' \subseteq \mathbb{T}T′⊆T.

    Thus, T=T′\mathbb{T} = \mathbb{T}'T=T′ ◻ :::

1.3 The Order Topology

::: {#def:Interval .definition} Definition 1.15 (interval). Let X\mathbb{X}X is a set having a simple order relation <<<. Given elements aaa and bbb of X\mathbb{X}X such that a<ba < ba<b, there are four subsets of X\mathbb{X}X that are called intervals determined by aaa and bbb:

  • (a,b)={x∣a<x<b}(a,b) = \{ x | a < x < b \}(a,b)={x∣a<x<b}

  • (a,b]={x∣a<x≤b}(a,b] = \{ x | a < x \le b \}(a,b]={x∣a<x≤b}

  • [a,b)={x∣a≤x<b}[a,b) = \{ x | a \le x < b \}[a,b)={x∣a≤x<b}

  • [a,b]={x∣a≤x≤b}[a,b] = \{ x | a \le x \le b \}[a,b]={x∣a≤x≤b}

(a,b)(a,b)(a,b) is called an open interval on X\mathbb{X}X . [a,b][a,b][a,b] is called an closed interval on X\mathbb{X}X . (a,b](a,b](a,b] and [a,b)[a,b)[a,b) is called half-open intervals. :::

::: {#def:OrderTopology .definition} Definition 1.16 (order topology). 9 Let X\mathbb{X}X be a set with a simple order relation; assume X\mathbb{X}X has more than one element. Let B\mathbb{B}B be the collection of all sets of the following types:

  • All open intervals (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) in X\mathbb{X}X .

  • All intervals of the form [a0,b)[a_{0},b)[a0​,b), where a0a_0a0​ is the smallest element(if exist) of X\mathbb{X}X .

  • All intervals of the form (a,b0](a,b_{0}](a,b0​], where b0b_0b0​ is the largest element(if exist) of X\mathbb{X}X .

The collection B\mathbb{B}B formed a basis for a topology on X\mathbb{X}X , which is called the order topology. :::

::: {#def:Ray .definition} Definition 1.17 (ray). 1011 If X\mathbb{X}X is an ordered set, and aaa is an element of X\mathbb{X}X , there are four subsets of X\mathbb{X}X that are called rays determined by aaa:

  • (a,+∞)={x∣x>a}(a,+\infty) = \{ x | x > a \}(a,+∞)={x∣x>a}

  • (−∞,a)={x∣x<a}(-\infty,a) = \{ x | x < a \}(−∞,a)={x∣x<a}

  • [a,+∞)={x∣x≥a}[a,+\infty) = \{ x | x \ge a \}[a,+∞)={x∣x≥a}

  • (−∞,a]={x∣x≤a}(-\infty,a] = \{ x | x \le a \}(−∞,a]={x∣x≤a}

(a,+∞)(a,+\infty)(a,+∞) and (−∞,a)(-\infty,a)(−∞,a) are called open rays. [a,+∞)[a,+\infty)[a,+∞) and (−∞,a](-\infty,a](−∞,a] are called closed rays. :::

1.4 The Product Topology

::: {#def:ProductTopology .definition} Definition 1.18 (product topology). Let X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y be topological spaces. The product topology on X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y having a basis B\mathbb{B}B containing all sets of the form U×VU \times VU×V, where UUU and VVV is open sets of X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y respectively. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.1. 12 If B\mathbb{B}B and C\mathbb{C}C is basis for the topology of X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y respectively, then the collection D={B×C∣B∈BandC∈C}\mathbb{D} = \{ B \times C | B \in \mathbb{B} and C \in \mathbb{C} \}D={B×C∣B∈BandC∈C} is a basis for the topology of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y :::

::: {#def:Projection .definition} Definition 1.19 (projection). Let π1:X×Y→X\pi_{1}: \mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y} \rightarrow \mathbb{X}π1​:X×Y→X be defined by the equation: π1(x,y)=x\pi_{1}(x,y) = xπ1​(x,y)=x

Let π2:X×Y→Y\pi_{2}: \mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}π2​:X×Y→Y be defined by the equation: π1(x,y)=y\pi_{1}(x,y) = yπ1​(x,y)=y

The maps π1\pi_{1}π1​ and π2\pi_{2}π2​ are called the projections of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y onto its first and second factors, respectively. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.2. 13 The collection S={π1−1(U)∣UopeninX}∪{π2−1(V)∣VopeninY}\mathbb{S} = \{ \pi_{1}^{-1}(U) | U open in \mathbb{X} \} \cup \{ \pi_{2}^{-1}(V) | V open in \mathbb{Y} \}S={π1−1​(U)∣UopeninX}∪{π2−1​(V)∣VopeninY} is a subbasis for the product topology on X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y. :::

::: {#def:BoxTopology .definition} Definition 1.20 (box topology). Let, X=X1×X2×⋯×XnorX1×X2×…\mathbb{X} = \mathbb{X}_{1} \times \mathbb{X}_{2} \times \dots \times \mathbb{X}_{n} \text{or} \mathbb{X}_{1} \times \mathbb{X}_{2} \times \dotsX=X1​×X2​×⋯×Xn​orX1​×X2​×…

In the first case, all the sets of the form U1×⋯×UnU_{1} \times \dots \times U_{n}U1​×⋯×Un​ where UiU_{i}Ui​ is a open set of Xi\mathbb{X}_{i}Xi​ form a basis.

In the second case, all the sets of the form U1×U2×…U_{1} \times U_{2} \times \dotsU1​×U2​×… where UiU_{i}Ui​ is a open set of Xi\mathbb{X}_{i}Xi​ also form a basis.

Topology defined in this way was called a box topology. :::

::: {#def:ProjectionMapping .definition} Definition 1.21 (product topology). []{#def:ProductTopologyInfinite label="def:ProductTopologyInfinite"}14 Let, X=X1×X2×⋯×XnorX1×X2×…\mathbb{X} = \mathbb{X}_{1} \times \mathbb{X}_{2} \times \dots \times \mathbb{X}_{n} \text{or} \mathbb{X}_{1} \times \mathbb{X}_{2} \times \dotsX=X1​×X2​×⋯×Xn​orX1​×X2​×…

Let πi\pi_{i}πi​ be the projection function15 that πi:X→Xi\pi_{i}: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{X}_{i}πi​:X→Xi​

And if x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X πi(x)=xi\pi_{i}(x) = x_{i}πi​(x)=xi​

All the set of the form πi−1(Ui)\pi_{i}^{-1}(U_{i})πi−1​(Ui​) where iii is arbitrary and UiU_{i}Ui​ is an open set of Xi\mathbb{X}_{i}Xi​ , form a subbasis of X\mathbb{X}X . The topology generated by this subbasis is called product topology. And X\mathbb{X}X is called a product space. :::

::: {#def:JTuple .definition} Definition 1.22 (J-tuple). Let JJJ be an index set16. Give a set X\mathbb{X}X , a J-tuple is defined as a function x:J→Xx: J \rightarrow \mathbb{X}x:J→X . If α\alphaα is an element of JJJ , x(α)x(\alpha)x(α) is often denoted by xαx_{\alpha}xα​ and is called the αth\alpha\text{th}αth coordinate of xxx . And the function xxx itself is often denoted by the symbol (xα)α∈J(x_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in J}(xα​)α∈J​

The set of all J-tuples of elements of X\mathbb{X}X is often denoted by XJ\mathbb{X}^{J}XJ . :::

::: {#def:CartesianProduct .definition} Definition 1.23 (cartesian product). Let {Aα}α∈J\{A_{\alpha}\}_{\alpha \in J}{Aα​}α∈J​ be an indexed family of sets; let X=⋃α∈JAα\mathbb{X} = \bigcup_{\alpha \in J} A_{\alpha}X=⋃α∈J​Aα​ . The cartesian product of this indexed family is denoted by ∏α∈JAα\displaystyle \prod_{\alpha \in J} A_{\alpha}α∈J∏​Aα​

And is defined to be the set of all J-tuples (xα)α∈J(x_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in J}(xα​)α∈J​ of elements of X\mathbb{X}X such that xα∈Aαx_{\alpha} \in A_{\alpha}xα​∈Aα​ for each α∈J\alpha \in Jα∈J . That is, it is the set of all functions x:J→⋃α∈JAαx: J \rightarrow \bigcup_{\alpha \in J} A_{\alpha}x:J→⋃α∈J​Aα​ such that x(α)∈Aαx(\alpha) \in A_{\alpha}x(α)∈Aα​ for each α∈J\alpha \in Jα∈J . :::

::: {#theorem:ComparisonOfBoxProductTopology .theorem} Theorem 1.3 (Comparison of the box and product topologies). 17 The box topology on ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ has a basis all sets of the form ∏Uα\prod U_{\alpha}∏Uα​ where UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ is open in XαX_{\alpha}Xα​ for each α\alphaα . The product topology on ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ has a basis all sets of the form ∏Uα\prod U_{\alpha}∏Uα​ where UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ is open in XαX_{\alpha}Xα​ for each α\alphaα and UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ equals Xα\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Xα​ except for finitely many values of α\alphaα . :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.4. 18 Suppose the topology on each space Xα\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Xα​ is given by a basis Xα\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Xα​ . The collection of all sets of the form ∏α∈JBα\prod_{\alpha \in J} B_{\alpha}∏α∈J​Bα​ where Bα∈BαB_{\alpha} \in \mathbb{B}_{\alpha}Bα​∈Bα​ form a basis for the box topology on ∏α∈JXα\prod _{\alpha \in J} \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏α∈J​Xα​ .

The collection of all sets of the same form, where Bα∈BαB_{\alpha} \in \mathbb{B}_{\alpha}Bα​∈Bα​ for finitely many indices α\alphaα and Bα=XαB_{\alpha} = \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Bα​=Xα​ for all the remaining indices, will form a basis for the product topology ∏α∈JXα\prod_{\alpha \in J}\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏α∈J​Xα​ . :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.5. 19 Let AαA_{\alpha}Aα​ be a subspace of Xα\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Xα​ , for each α∈J\alpha \in Jα∈J . Then ∏Aα\prod A_{\alpha}∏Aα​ is a subspace of ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ if both products are given the box topology, or if both products are given the product topology. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.6. 20 If each space Xα\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Xα​ is a Hausdorff space, then ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ is a Hausdorff space in both the box and product topologies. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.7. Let {Xα}\{ \mathbb{X}_{\alpha} \}{Xα​} be an indexed family of spaces; let Aα⊆XαA_{\alpha} \subseteq \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Aα​⊆Xα​ for each α\alphaα . If ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ is given either the product or the box topology, then ∏Aα‾=∏Aα‾\prod \overline{A_{\alpha}} = \overline{\prod A_{\alpha}}∏Aα​​=∏Aα​​ :::

::: proof Proof. Let πα\pi_{\alpha}πα​ represent the projection mapping.

Let xxx be an element of ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ . Let VVV be an open set in ∏Xα\prod \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}∏Xα​ that containing xxx .

If x∈∏Aα‾x \in \prod \overline{A_{\alpha}}x∈∏Aα​​ , then πα(V)\pi_{\alpha}(V)πα​(V) is a open set in Xα\mathbb{X}_{\alpha}Xα​ that containing xαx_{\alpha}xα​ . Thus πα(V)\pi_{\alpha}(V)πα​(V) intersect with AαA_{\alpha}Aα​ . Thus VVV intersect with ∏Aα\prod A_{\alpha}∏Aα​ . Thus x∈∏Aα‾x \in \overline{\prod A_{\alpha}}x∈∏Aα​​ .

If x∈∏Aα‾x \in \overline{\prod A_{\alpha}}x∈∏Aα​​ . Let UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ be an open set of AαA_{\alpha}Aα​ that contain xαx_{\alpha}xα​ . Thus x∈∏Aα‾x \in \prod \overline{A_{\alpha}}x∈∏Aα​​ . ◻ :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.8. Let f:A→∏α∈JXαf: A \rightarrow \prod_{\alpha \in J} \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}f:A→∏α∈J​Xα​ be given by the equation f(a)=(fα(a))α∈Jf(a) = ( f_{\alpha}(a) )_{\alpha \in J}f(a)=(fα​(a))α∈J​ where fα:A→Xαf_{\alpha} : A \rightarrow \mathbb{X}_{\alpha}fα​:A→Xα​ for each α\alphaα . ::: proof Proof. Let πα\pi_{\alpha}πα​ be the projection mapping

1.5 The Subspace Topology

::: {#def:SubspaceTopology .definition} Definition 1.24 (subspace topology). Let X\mathbb{X}X be a topological space with topology T\mathbb{T}T . If YYY is a subset of X\mathbb{X}X , the collection TY={Y∩U∣U∈T}\mathbb{T}_{Y} = \{ Y \cap U | U \in \mathbb{T} \}TY​={Y∩U∣U∈T} is a topology on YYY , called the subspace topology.

YYY is also called a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.6. 21 If B\mathbb{B}B is basis for the topology of X\mathbb{X}X , YYY is a subset of X\mathbb{X}X then the collection BY={B∩Y∣B∈B}\mathbb{B}_{Y} = \{ B \cap Y | B \in \mathbb{B} \}BY​={B∩Y∣B∈B} is a basis for the subspace topology on YYY :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.7. 22 Let YYY be a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X . If UUU is open in YYY and YYY is open in X\mathbb{X}X , then UUU is open in X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.9. 23 If AAA is a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X and BBB is a subspace of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , then the product topology on A×BA \times BA×B is the same as the topology A×BA \times BA×B inherits as a subspace of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y :::

::: proof Proof. Let BX\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}BX​ and BY\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}BY​ and BXY\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{XY}}BXY​ be basis of topology of X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y and X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y respectively. Let BX′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}'BX′​ and BY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}'BY′​ and BXY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{XY}}'BXY′​ be basis of topology of AAA and AAA and A×BA \times BA×B respectively. We will show that BX′×BY′=BXY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}' \times \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}' = \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{XY}}'BX′​×BY′​=BXY′​. Thus, the product topology on A×BA \times BA×B is the same as the topology A×BA \times BA×B inherits as a subspace of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y .

First, every element in BX′×BY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}' \times \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}'BX′​×BY′​ can be represented by BA∩A×BB∩B=BA×BB∩A×B∈BXY′B_{A} \cap A \times B_{B} \cap B = B_{A} \times B_{B} \cap A \times B \in \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{XY}}'BA​∩A×BB​∩B=BA​×BB​∩A×B∈BXY′​ where BA∈BX′,BB∈BY′B_{A} \in \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}', B_{B} \in \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}'BA​∈BX′​,BB​∈BY′​. Thus BX′×BY′⊆BXY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}' \times \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}' \subseteq \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{XY}}'BX′​×BY′​⊆BXY′​.

Next, we show that BX′×BY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}' \times \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}'BX′​×BY′​ generate the topology A×BA \times BA×B inherits as a subspace of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y . For any open set UUU in X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y , and ∀x∈U∩A×B,∃BX×BY∈BXY,x∈BX×BY⊆X×Y\forall x \in U \cap A \times B, \exists B_{\mathbb{X}} \times B_{\mathbb{Y}} \in \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{XY}}, x \in B_{\mathbb{X}} \times B_{\mathbb{Y}} \subseteq \mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}∀x∈U∩A×B,∃BX​×BY​∈BXY​,x∈BX​×BY​⊆X×Y. Thus x∈BX×BY∩A×B⊆A×B,BX×BY∩A×B∈BX′×BY′x \in B_{\mathbb{X}} \times B_{\mathbb{Y}} \cap A \times B \subseteq A \times B, B_{\mathbb{X}} \times B_{\mathbb{Y}} \cap A \times B \in \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}' \times \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}'x∈BX​×BY​∩A×B⊆A×B,BX​×BY​∩A×B∈BX′​×BY′​. Thus BX′×BY′\mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{X}}' \times \mathbb{B}_{\mathbb{Y}}'BX′​×BY′​ generate the topology A×BA \times BA×B inherits as a subspace of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y .gi ◻ :::

::: {#def:OrderedSquare .definition} Definition 1.25 (ordered square). Let I=[0,1]I = [0,1]I=[0,1]. The set I×II \times II×I in the dictionary order 24 topology will be called ordered square, and denoted by Io2I_{o}^{2}Io2​ :::

::: {#def:Convex .definition} Definition 1.26 (convex). Given an ordered set X\mathbb{X}X , let us say that a subset Y\mathbb{Y}Y of X\mathbb{X}X is convex in X\mathbb{X}X if for each pair of points a<ba < ba<b of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , the entire interval (a,b)(a,b)(a,b) of points of X\mathbb{X}X lies in Y\mathbb{Y}Y :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.10. 25 Let X\mathbb{X}X be an ordered set in the order topology. Let Y\mathbb{Y}Y be a subset of X\mathbb{X}X that is convex in X\mathbb{X}X . Then the order topology on Y\mathbb{Y}Y is the same as the topology Y\mathbb{Y}Y inherits as a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: proof Proof. Consider the ray (a,+∞)(a,+\infty)(a,+∞) in X\mathbb{X}X . If a∈Ya \in \mathbb{Y}a∈Y, then (a,+∞)∩Y={x∣x∈Yandx>a}(a,+\infty) \cap \mathbb{Y} = \{ x | x \in \mathbb{Y} and x > a \}(a,+∞)∩Y={x∣x∈Yandx>a}

This is an open ray of the ordered set of Y\mathbb{Y}Y . if a∉Ya \notin Ya∈/Y, then aaa is either a lower bound on Y\mathbb{Y}Y or an upper bound on Y\mathbb{Y}Y , since Y\mathbb{Y}Y is convex. In the former case, the set (a,+∞)∩Y(a,+\infty) \cap \mathbb{Y}(a,+∞)∩Y equals all of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , in the latter case, it is empty.

A similar remark shows that the intersection of the rat (−∞,a)(-\infty,a)(−∞,a) with Y\mathbb{Y}Y is either an open ray of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , or Y\mathbb{Y}Y itself, or empty. Since the sets (a,+∞)Y(a,+\infty) \cal \mathbb{Y}(a,+∞)Y and (−∞,a)∩Y(-\infty,a) \cap \mathbb{Y}(−∞,a)∩Y form a subbasis for the subspace topology on Y\mathbb{Y}Y , and since each is open in the order topology, the order topology contains the subspace topology.

To prove the reverse, note that any open ray of Y\mathbb{Y}Y equals the intersection of an open ray of X\mathbb{X}X with Y\mathbb{Y}Y , so it is open in the subspace topology on Y\mathbb{Y}Y . Since the open rays of Y\mathbb{Y}Y are a subbasis for the order topology on Y\mathbb{Y}Y , this topology is contained in the subspace topology. ◻ :::

1.6 Closed Sets and Limit Points

::: {#def:Closed .definition} Definition 1.27 (closed). 28 A subset AAA of a topological space is said to be closed if the set X−A\mathbb{X}-AX−A is open. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.11. 29 Let X\mathbb{X}X be a topological space. Then the following conditions hold

  1. ∅\emptyset∅ and X\mathbb{X}X are closed.

  2. Arbitrary intersections of closed sets are closed

  3. Finite unions of closed sets are closed :::

::: {#def:ClosedIn .definition} Definition 1.28 (closed in). Let X\mathbb{X}X be a topological space; let Y\mathbb{Y}Y be a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X . We say that a set AAA is closed in Y\mathbb{Y}Y if AAA is a subset of Y\mathbb{Y}Y and AAA is closed in the subspace topology of Y\mathbb{Y}Y :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.12. Let Y\mathbb{Y}Y be a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X . Then a set AAA is closed in Y\mathbb{Y}Y if and only if it equals the intersection of a closed set of X\mathbb{X}X with Y\mathbb{Y}Y :::

::: proof Proof. First we proof that if AAA is closed in Y\mathbb{Y}Y , then ∃B⊆X,B∩Y=A\exists B \subseteq \mathbb{X}, B \cap \mathbb{Y} = A∃B⊆X,B∩Y=A . As the origin topology form a surjective map to its subspace topology, there exists a BBB closed in X\mathbb{X}X that Y−A=(X−B)∩Y\mathbb{Y} - A = ( \mathbb{X} - B ) \cap \mathbb{Y}Y−A=(X−B)∩Y . Then B∩Y=AB \cap \mathbb{Y} = AB∩Y=A

Conversely, if ∃B⊆X,B∩Y=A\exists B \subseteq \mathbb{X}, B \cap \mathbb{Y} = A∃B⊆X,B∩Y=A . Then, Y−A=(X−B)∩Y\mathbb{Y} - A = ( \mathbb{X} - B ) \cap \mathbb{Y}Y−A=(X−B)∩Y . Then X−B\mathbb{X}-BX−B is open in Y\mathbb{Y}Y , Y−A\mathbb{Y}-AY−A is open in Y\mathbb{Y}Y . Then AAA is closed in Y\mathbb{Y}Y ◻ :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.13. 30 Let Y\mathbb{Y}Y be a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X . If AAA is closed in Y\mathbb{Y}Y and Y\mathbb{Y}Y is closed in X\mathbb{X}X , then AAA is closed in X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: {#def:Interior .definition} Definition 1.29 (interior). Given a subset AAA of a topological space X\mathbb{X}X , the interior of AAA is defined as the union of all open sets contained in AAA . Denoted by Int(A)Int(A)Int(A). :::

::: {#def:Closure .definition} Definition 1.30 (closure). Given a subset AAA of a topological space X\mathbb{X}X , the closure of AAA is defined as the intersection of all closed sets containing AAA . Denoted by Cl(A)Cl(A)Cl(A) or A‾\overline{A}A :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.14. 3132 Let Y\mathbb{Y}Y be a subspace of a topological space X\mathbb{X}X ; let AAA be a subset of X\mathbb{X}X . Let A‾\overline{A}A denote the closure of AAA in X\mathbb{X}X . Then the closure of AAA in Y\mathbb{Y}Y equals A‾∩Y\overline{A} \cap \mathbb{Y}A∩Y :::

::: {#def:Intersect .definition} Definition 1.31 (intersect). We say that a set AAA intersects BBB if A∩BA \cap BA∩B is not empty. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.15. Let AAA be a subset of the topological space X\mathbb{X}X

  1. The x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A if and only if every open set UUU containing xxx intersect AAA .

  2. Supposing the topology of X\mathbb{X}X is given by a basis, then x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A if and only if every basis element BBB containing xxx intersects AAA :::

::: proof Proof. There are only two types of closed set UUU in X\mathbb{X}X :

  1. U⊇A‾U \supseteq \overline{A}U⊇A

  2. U∩A≠AU \cap A \neq AU∩A=A

Thus, there are only two types of open set UUU in X\mathbb{X}X respectively.

  1. UUU does not intersects AAA .

  2. U∩A‾≠∅U \cap \overline{A} \neq \emptysetU∩A=∅

  3. If x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A , then every open set containing xxx is the open set of second type, thus every open set containing xxx intersects AAA

    If every open set containing xxx intersect A\mathbb{A}A , suppose x∉A‾x \notin \overline{A}x∈/A . Then X−A‾\mathbb{X} - \overline{A}X−A is a open set containing x, however, it does not intersects AAA . Thus, x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A .

  4. If x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A , as every basis element of X\mathbb{X}X is a open set, thus every basis element containing xxx intersects A\mathbb{A}A

    If every open set containing xxx intersect A\mathbb{A}A , suppose x∉A‾x \notin \overline{A}x∈/A .

    As every open sets can be represented by union of basis. Let X−A‾=B1∪B2∪B3∪⋯∪B1′∪B2′∪B3′∪…\mathbb{X} - \overline{A} = B_{1} \cup B_{2} \cup B_{3} \cup \dots \cup B_{1}' \cup B_{2}' \cup B_{3}' \cup \dotsX−A=B1​∪B2​∪B3​∪⋯∪B1′​∪B2′​∪B3′​∪… where BBB are bases containing xxx , and B′B'B′ are bases that does not contain xxx .

    Thus, x∈B1∪B2∪B3∪⋯⊆X−A‾x \in B_{1} \cup B_{2} \cup B_{3} \cup \dots \subseteq \mathbb{X} - \overline{A}x∈B1​∪B2​∪B3​∪⋯⊆X−A

    Then B1∪B2∪B3∪…B_{1} \cup B_{2} \cup B_{3} \cup \dotsB1​∪B2​∪B3​∪… that is a open set can be generated by all the bases containing xxx , however, that does not intersects AAA . So, x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A .

 ◻ :::

::: {#def:Neighbourhood .definition} Definition 1.32 (neighbourhood). 33 If we say UUU is a neighbourhood of xxx in X\mathbb{X}X , then UUU is an open set in X\mathbb{X}X containing xxx :::

::: {#def:LimitPoint .definition} Definition 1.33 (limit point, point of accumulation, cluster point). 34 If AAA is a subset of topological space X\mathbb{X}X .We say that xxx is a limit point of AAA if and only if every open sets containing xxx intersects A with some points other than xxx .

This condition is also equivalent to the condition that if xxx is a limit point of AAA if and only if x∈A−{x}‾x \in \overline{A-\{x\}}x∈A−{x}​ :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.16. 35 Let AAA be a subset of topological space X\mathbb{X}X ; let A′A'A′ be the set of all limit points of AAA . Then A‾=A∪A′\overline{A} = A \cup A'A=A∪A′ :::

::: corollary Corollary 1.1. 36 A subset of a topological space is closed if and only if it contains all its limit point. :::

::: {#def:Converge .definition} Definition 1.34 (converge). 37 We say that a sequence of x1,x2,x3…x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3} \dotsx1​,x2​,x3​… converge to xxx . When for every neighbourhood UUU of xxx , there exists a positive integer NNN , such that for all n>Nn > Nn>N , xn∈Ux_{n} \in Uxn​∈U . :::

::: {#def:HausdorffSpace .definition} Definition 1.35 (Hausdorff space). A topological space is called a Hausdorff space, if for every distinct x1x_{1}x1​ , x2x_{2}x2​ in X\mathbb{X}X , there exists disjoint neighbourhood of U1U_{1}U1​ , U2U_{2}U2​ of x1x_{1}x1​ , x2x_{2}x2​ in X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.17. 3839 Every finite point set in a Hausdorff space X\mathbb{X}X is closed. :::

::: proof Proof. Let AAA be a finite point set in a Hausdorff space X\mathbb{X}X .

Suppose AAA only have one element. Then for every x∈X−Ax\in\mathbb{X}-Ax∈X−A , there exists a neighbourhood of xxx that does not intersect with AAA . So AAA is closed.

Suppose AAA is a closed finite point set. We take x0∈X−Ax_{0}\in\mathbb{X}-Ax0​∈X−A . As finite union of closed set is closed, A∪{x0}A\cup\{x_{0}\}A∪{x0​} is closed.

Then, from induction, all finite point set in a Hausdorff space is closed. ◻ :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.18. If X\mathbb{X}X is a Hausdorff space, then a sequence of points in X\mathbb{X}X converges to at most one point. :::

::: proof Proof. Suppose that the following sequence x1,x2,x3…x_{1}, x_{2}, x_{3}\dotsx1​,x2​,x3​…

Converge to more than one points say y1,y2,y3…y_{1}, y_{2}, y_{3}\dotsy1​,y2​,y3​…

Then there exists n1,n2,n3…,U1,U2,U3…n_{1}, n_{2}, n_{3}\dots, U_{1}, U_{2}, U_{3}\dotsn1​,n2​,n3​…,U1​,U2​,U3​…

Such that for n>nin > n_{i}n>ni​ xn∈Ui,yi∈Uix_{n} \in U_{i}, y_{i} \in U_{i}xn​∈Ui​,yi​∈Ui​

If we take disjoint U1,U2U_{1}, U_{2}U1​,U2​ which is possible as this is a Hausdorff space.

Then the previews condition does not stand. So, every sequence of points in a Hausdorff space can only converge to at most one point. ◻ :::

::: {#def:Limit .definition} Definition 1.36 (limit). If a sequence xnx_{n}xn​ of points in Hausdorff space converge to the point xxx , we denote this by xn→xx_{n} \rightarrow xxn​→x and we say the limit of xnx_{n}xn​ is xxx . :::

::: {#def:T1Axiom .definition} Definition 1.37 ( T1T_{1}T1​ axiom). The condition that all finite point set of a topological space is closed is called T1T_{1}T1​ axiom. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.19. Let X\mathbb{X}X be a space satisfying the T1T_{1}T1​ axiom; let AAA be a subset of X\mathbb{X}X . Then the point xxx is a limit point of AAA if and only if every neighbourhood of xxx contains infinitely many points of AAA . :::

::: proof Proof. If every neighbourhood of xxx contains infinitely many point of AAA . Than every neighbourhood of xxx intersect with AAA with infinite element other than xxx , then xxx is a limit point of AAA .

If xxx is a limit point of AAA . Suppose that there exists a open set UUU containing xxx and intersect with AAA for finite many points. Let U′=U∩(A−x)U' = U \cap ( A - x )U′=U∩(A−x)

Then, x∉U′x \notin U'x∈/U′ . Let U′′=U−U′U'' = U - U'U′′=U−U′

Then U′′U''U′′ is open as U′U'U′ is a finite point set and U′′=U−U′=U∩(X−U′)U'' = U - U' = U \cap (\mathbb{X} - U')U′′=U−U′=U∩(X−U′)

Also, x∈U′′x \in U''x∈U′′ . Thus, U′′U''U′′ is a open set containing xxx that only intersect AAA with xxx or do not intersect AAA . This is a contradiction of x is a limit point. Thus there does not exists a open set UUU containing xxx and intersect with AAA for finite many points. ◻ :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.20. 40 Every simply ordered set is a Hausdorff space in order topology. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.21. 41 The product of two Hausdorff space is a Hausdorff space. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.22. 42 A subspace of a Hausdorff space is a Hausdorff space. :::

1.7 Continuous Function

::: {#def:ContinuousRelativeTo .definition} Definition 1.38 (continuous). []{#def:Continuous label="def:Continuous"}43 Let X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y be topological spaces. A function f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y is said to be continuous if for each open subset VVV of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , the set f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) is an open subset of X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.23. Let X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y be topological spaces; let f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y}f:X→Y . Then the following are equivalent.

  1. fff is continuous.

  2. For every subset AAA of XXX , one has f(A‾)⊆f(A)‾f(\overline{A})\subseteq\overline{f(A)}f(A)⊆f(A)​ .

  3. For every closed set BBB of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , the set f−1(B)f^{-1}(B)f−1(B) is closed in X\mathbb{X}X .

  4. For each x∈Xx\in\mathbb{X}x∈X and each neighbourhood of VVV of f(x)f(x)f(x) , there is a neighbourhood UUU of xxx such that f(U)⊆Vf(U) \subseteq Vf(U)⊆V . :::

::: proof Proof. 1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3:

Let AAA be a open set in Y\mathbb{Y}Y . f−1(Y−A)=X−f−1(A)f^{-1}(\mathbb{Y}-A) = \mathbb{X} - f^{-1}(A)f−1(Y−A)=X−f−1(A) .

3 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 1:

Let AAA be a closed set in Y\mathbb{Y}Y . f−1(Y−A)=X−f−1(A)f^{-1}(\mathbb{Y}-A) = \mathbb{X} - f^{-1}(A)f−1(Y−A)=X−f−1(A) .

1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 2:

For x∈A‾x \in \overline{A}x∈A , we take a open set f(x)∈U⊆Yf(x) \in U \subseteq \mathbb{Y}f(x)∈U⊆Y . Thus x∈f−1(U)∩A≠∅x \in f^{-1}(U) \cap A \neq \emptysetx∈f−1(U)∩A=∅ . Thus U∩f(A)≠∅U \cap f(A) \neq \emptysetU∩f(A)=∅ . So f(x)∈f(A)‾f(x) \in \overline{f(A)}f(x)∈f(A)​ . Thus f(A‾)⊆f(A)‾f(\overline{A})\subseteq\overline{f(A)}f(A)⊆f(A)​ .

2 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 3:

Suppose fff is not continuous. Then there must exists VVV , such that f−1(V)=Uf^{-1}(V) = Uf−1(V)=U is not closed. Thus U‾⊃B=f−1(A)\overline{U} \supset B = f^{-1}(A)U⊃B=f−1(A) . Thus fB‾⊃Af{\overline{B}} \supset AfB⊃A . However f(B‾)⊆f(B)‾=Af(\overline{B}) \subseteq \overline{f(B)} = Af(B)⊆f(B)​=A . There is a contradiction. So fff must be continuous.

1 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 4:

For every neighbourhood VVV of f(x)f(x)f(x) , f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) is a neighbourhood of xxx that f(f−1(V))⊆Vf(f^{-1}(V)) \subseteq Vf(f−1(V))⊆V .

4 ⇒\Rightarrow⇒ 1:

We take a open set VVV of Y\mathbb{Y}Y . Let SSS be the collection of all open set UUU in X\mathbb{X}X such that f(U)⊆Vf(U) \subseteq Vf(U)⊆V . The set cannot be empty unless f−1(V)=∅f^{-1}(V) = \emptysetf−1(V)=∅ . Let U0U_{0}U0​ denote the union of all the element in SSS . We prove that U0=f−1(V)U_{0} = f^{-1}(V)U0​=f−1(V) .

For all element x∈U0x \in U_{0}x∈U0​ , f(x)∈Vf(x) \in Vf(x)∈V . Thus U0⊆f−1(V)U_{0} \subseteq f^{-1}(V)U0​⊆f−1(V) .

For all element x∈f−1(V)x \in f^{-1}(V)x∈f−1(V) . There is a U′U'U′ such that x∈U′,f(U′)⊆Vx \in U', f(U')\subseteq Vx∈U′,f(U′)⊆V . This follows from the condition 4. Thus U′∈SU' \in SU′∈S . Thus x∈U0x \in U_{0}x∈U0​ . Thus U0⊆f−1(V)U_{0} \subseteq f^{-1}(V)U0​⊆f−1(V) . As U0U_{0}U0​ is union of open set, U0U_{0}U0​ is also open. Thus, f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) is also open.

Thus fff is continuous. ◻ :::

::: {#def:Homeomorphism .definition} Definition 1.39 (homeomorphism). 44 Let X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y be topological space; let f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y be a bijection. If both the function fff and the inverse function f−1:Y→Xf^{-1}: \mathbb{Y} \rightarrow \mathbb{X}f−1:Y→X are continuous, then f is called a homeomorphism :::

::: {#def:TopologicalImbedding .definition} Definition 1.40 (topological imbedding). Suppose that f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y is an injective continuous map, where X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y are topological spaces. Let Z\mathbb{Z}Z be the image set f(X)f(\mathbb{X})f(X) , considered as a subspace of Y\mathbb{Y}Y ; then the function f′:X→Zf': \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}f′:X→Z obtained by restricting the range of fff is bijective. If f′f'f′ happens to be a homeomorphism of X\mathbb{X}X with Z\mathbb{Z}Z , we say that the map f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y is a topological imbedding, or simply an imbedding, of X\mathbb{X}X in Y\mathbb{Y}Y . :::

::: {#theorem:RulesForConstructingContinuousFunctions .theorem} Theorem 1.24 (Rules for constructing continuous functions). Let X\mathbb{X}X , Y\mathbb{Y}Y , and Z\mathbb{Z}Z be topological spaces.

  1. (Constant function) If f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y maps all of X\mathbb{X}X into the single point y0y_{0}y0​ of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , then fff is continuous.

  2. (Inclusion) If AAA is a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X , the inclusion function j:A→Xj: A \rightarrow \mathbb{X}j:A→X is continuous.

  3. (Composites) If f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y and g:Y→Zg:\mathbb{Y}\rightarrow\mathbb{Z}g:Y→Z are continuous, then the map g∘f:X→Zg \circ f: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}g∘f:X→Z is continuous.

  4. (Restricting the domain) If f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y is continuous, and if AAA is a subspace of X\mathbb{X}X , then the restriction function f∣A:A→Yf|A : A \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f∣A:A→Y is continuous.

  5. (Restricting or expanding the range) Let f:X→Yf:\mathbb{X}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y}f:X→Y is continuous. Let Z\mathbb{Z}Z be a subspace of Y\mathbb{Y}Y containing the image f(X)f(\mathbb{X})f(X) , the function h:X→Zh: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow \mathbb{Z}h:X→Z obtained by restricting the range of fff is continuous. If Z\mathbb{Z}Z is a space having Y\mathbb{Y}Y as a subspace, then the function h:X→Yh: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y}h:X→Y obtained by expanding the range of fff is continuous.

  6. (Local formulation of continuity) The map f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y}f:X→Y is continuous if X\mathbb{X}X can be written as the union of open sets UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ such set f∣Uαf|U_{\alpha}f∣Uα​ is continuous for each α\alphaα :::

::: proof Proof.

  1. f−1(U)f^{-1}(U)f−1(U) of any open set UUU is X\mathbb{X}X , thus fff is continuous.

  2. For every open subset UUU of X\mathbb{X}X , j−1(U)=U∩Aj^{-1}(U) = U\cap Aj−1(U)=U∩A is continuous in AAA . Thus jjj is a continuous function.

  3. For every open subset UUU of Z\mathbb{Z}Z , f−1(U)f^{-1}(U)f−1(U) is open in Y\mathbb{Y}Y , and g−1(f−1(U))g^{-1}(f^{-1}(U))g−1(f−1(U)) is open in X\mathbb{X}X . Thus, g∘fg \circ fg∘f is continuous

  4. For every open subset UUU of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , f−1(U)f^{-1}(U)f−1(U) is open in X\mathbb{X}X , thus f−1(U)∩Af^{-1}(U)\cap Af−1(U)∩A is open in AAA . Thus the function f∣Af|Af∣A is continuous.

  5. If Z\mathbb{Z}Z is a subspace of Y\mathbb{Y}Y , then every open subset of Z\mathbb{Z}Z can be represented as U∩ZU\cap\mathbb{Z}U∩Z , where UUU is a open subset of Y\mathbb{Y}Y . Thus h−1(U∩Z)=g−1(Z)∩g−1(U)=X∩g−1(U)h^{-1}(U\cap\mathbb{Z})=g^{-1}(\mathbb{Z})\cap g^{-1}(U) = \mathbb{X}\cap g^{-1}(U)h−1(U∩Z)=g−1(Z)∩g−1(U)=X∩g−1(U) which is a open subset of XXX , thus hhh is continuous.

    If Y\mathbb{Y}Y is a subspace of Z\mathbb{Z}Z . Then we take a open subset UUU of Z\mathbb{Z}Z . h−1(U)=g(−1)(U∩Y)h^{-1}(U) = g^(-1)(U\cap \mathbb{Y})h−1(U)=g(−1)(U∩Y) which is open in X\mathbb{X}X , thus hhh is continuous.

  6. if f∣Uαf|U_{\alpha}f∣Uα​ is continuous for each α\alphaα . For every open subset UUU of Y\mathbb{Y}Y . U=∪α(Uα∩U)U = \cup_{\alpha} (U_{\alpha}\cap U)U=∪α​(Uα​∩U) where Uα∩UU_{\alpha}\cap UUα​∩U is open both in UαU_{\alpha}Uα​ and in Y\mathbb{Y}Y .

    Thus,

    f−1(U)=f−1(∪α(Uα∩U))=∪α((f∣Uα)−1(Uα∩U))\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(U) &=& f^{-1}(\cup_{\alpha} (U_{\alpha}\cap U)) \\ &=& \cup_{\alpha} ((f|U_{\alpha})^{-1}(U_{\alpha}\cap U)) \end{aligned}f−1(U)​==​f−1(∪α​(Uα​∩U))∪α​((f∣Uα​)−1(Uα​∩U))​

    and each (f∣Uα)−1(Uα∩U)(f|U_{\alpha})^{-1}(U_{\alpha}\cap U)(f∣Uα​)−1(Uα​∩U) is open, thus f−1(U)f^{-1}(U)f−1(U) is open.

 ◻ :::

::: {#theorem:ThePastingLemma .theorem} Theorem 1.25 (The pasting lemma). 45 Let X=A∪B\mathbb{X} = A \cup BX=A∪B , where A,BA,BA,B are closed in X\mathbb{X}X . Let f:A→Yf: A\rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:A→Y and g:B→Yg: B \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}g:B→Y be continuous. If f(x)=g(x)f(x)=g(x)f(x)=g(x) for every x∈A∩Bx\in A\cap Bx∈A∩B , then f,gf,gf,g combine to give a continuous function h:X→Yh: \mathbb{X}\rightarrow\mathbb{Y}h:X→Y , defined by setting h(x)=f(x),x∈Ah(x)=f(x),x\in Ah(x)=f(x),x∈A and h(x)=g(x),x∈Bh(x)=g(x),x\in Bh(x)=g(x),x∈B . :::

::: {#def:CoordinateFunctions .theorem} Theorem 1.26 (Maps into products). []{#theorem:MapsIntoProducts label="theorem:MapsIntoProducts"} 46 Let f:A→X×Yf: A \rightarrow \mathbb{X}\times\mathbb{Y}f:A→X×Y be given by the equation f(a)=(f1(a),f2(a))f(a) = (f_{1}(a),f_{2}(a))f(a)=(f1​(a),f2​(a))

Then, the function fff is continuous if and only if the functions f1:A→X,f2:A→Yf_{1}: A \rightarrow \mathbb{X}, f_{2}: A \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f1​:A→X,f2​:A→Y are continuous. :::

::: proof Proof. Let π1,π2\pi_{1},\pi_{2}π1​,π2​ be the projection function

π1:X×Y→Xπ2:X×Y→Y\begin{aligned} \pi_{1}&:& \mathbb{X}\times\mathbb{Y} \rightarrow \mathbb{X} \\ \pi_{2}&:& \mathbb{X}\times\mathbb{Y} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y} \end{aligned}π1​π2​​::​X×Y→XX×Y→Y​

We first proof that if UUU is an open subset of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y , f−1(U)=f1−1(π1(U))∩f2−1(π2(U))f^{-1}(U) = f_{1}^{-1}(\pi_{1}(U)) \cap f_{2}^{-1}(\pi_{2}(U))f−1(U)=f1−1​(π1​(U))∩f2−1​(π2​(U))

Let x×y∈Ux \times y \in Ux×y∈U , f−1(x×y)f^{-1}(x \times y)f−1(x×y) contains all aaa such that f(a)=x×yf(a) = x \times yf(a)=x×y .

Thus f−1(U)⊆f1−1(π1(U))∩f2−1(π2(U))f^{-1}(U) \subseteq f_{1}^{-1}(\pi_{1}(U)) \cap f_{2}^{-1}(\pi_{2}(U))f−1(U)⊆f1−1​(π1​(U))∩f2−1​(π2​(U)) .

Thus f−1(U)=f1−1(π1(U))∩f2−1(π2(U))f^{-1}(U) = f_{1}^{-1}(\pi_{1}(U)) \cap f_{2}^{-1}(\pi_{2}(U))f−1(U)=f1−1​(π1​(U))∩f2−1​(π2​(U))

Let UUU be any open subset of X×Y\mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{Y}X×Y

f−1(U)=f1−1(π1(U))∩f2−1(π2(U))f^{-1}(U) = f_{1}^{-1}(\pi_{1}(U)) \cap f_{2}^{-1}(\pi_{2}(U))f−1(U)=f1−1​(π1​(U))∩f2−1​(π2​(U))

1.8 Metric Topology

::: {#def:Distance .definition} Definition 1.41 (metric). []{#def:Metric label="def:Metric"} A metric on a set X\mathbb{X}X is a function d:X×X→Rd: \mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}d:X×X→R having the following properties:

  1. d(x,y)≥0d(x,y) \geq 0d(x,y)≥0 for all x,y∈Xx,y \in \mathbb{X}x,y∈X ; equality hold if and only if x=yx = yx=y

  2. d(x,y)=d(y,x),∀x,y∈Xd(x,y) = d(y,x), \forall x,y \in \mathbb{X}d(x,y)=d(y,x),∀x,y∈X

  3. (Triangle Inequality) d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z),∀x,y,z∈Xd(x,y) + d(y,z) \geq d(x,z), \forall x,y,z \in \mathbb{X}d(x,y)+d(y,z)≥d(x,z),∀x,y,z∈X

Given a metric ddd on X\mathbb{X}X , the number d(x,y)d(x,y)d(x,y) is often called the distancebetween xxx and yyy in the metric ddd . :::

::: {#def:EpsilonBallCenteredAtX .definition} Definition 1.42 ( ϵ\epsilonϵ -ball centered at xxx ). *48 Given metric ddd on a set X\mathbb{X}X and ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 . The set

Bd(x,ϵ)={y∣d(x,y)<ϵ}B_{d}(x,\epsilon) = \{ y | d(x,y) < \epsilon \}Bd​(x,ϵ)={y∣d(x,y)<ϵ}

is called ϵ\epsilonϵ -ball centered at xxx .* :::

::: {#def:MetricTopology .definition} Definition 1.43 (metric topology). If ddd is a metric on the set X\mathbb{X}X , then the collection of all ϵ\epsilonϵ -balls Bd(x,ϵ)B_{d}(x,\epsilon)Bd​(x,ϵ) , such that x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X and ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 , is a basis for a topology on X\mathbb{X}X , called the metric topology induced by ddd . :::

::: {#def:MetricSpace .definition} Definition 1.44 (metrizable). []{#def:Metrizable label="def:Metrizable"} If X\mathbb{X}X is topological space, X\mathbb{X}X is said to be metrizable if there exists a metric ddd on the set X\mathbb{X}X that induces the topology of X\mathbb{X}X . A metric spaceis a metrizable space X\mathbb{X}X together with a specific metric ddd that gives the topology of X\mathbb{X}X . :::

::: {#def:Bounded .definition} Definition 1.45 (bounded). Let X\mathbb{X}X be a metric space with metric ddd . A subset AAA of X\mathbb{X}X is said to be bounded if there is some number MMM such that d(a1,a2)≤Md(a_{1},a_{2}) \leq Md(a1​,a2​)≤M for every pair a1a_{1}a1​ and a2a_{2}a2​ if points of AAA . :::

::: {#def:Diameter .definition} Definition 1.46 (diameter). Let X\mathbb{X}X be a metric space with metric ddd . Let AAA be a bounded subset of X\mathbb{X}X . Then diameter is defined to be diamA=sup⁡{d(a1,a2)∣a1,a2∈A}\mathrm{diam}A = \sup\{ d(a_{1},a_{2}) | a_{1}, a_{2} \in A \}diamA=sup{d(a1​,a2​)∣a1​,a2​∈A} :::

::: {#def:StandardBoundedMetric .theorem} Theorem 1.27. Let X\mathbb{X}X be a metric space with metric ddd . Define d‾:X×X→R\overline{d}: \mathbb{X} \times \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}d:X×X→R by the equation d‾(x,y)=min{d(x,y),1}\overline{d}(x,y) = min\{ d(x,y),1 \}d(x,y)=min{d(x,y),1}

Then d‾\overline{d}d is a metric that induces the same topology as ddd .

The metric d‾\overline{d}d is called the standard bounded metriccorresponding to ddd :::

::: proof Proof. It is obvious that d‾\overline{d}d is a metric.

To prove that ddd and d‾\overline{d}d induces the same topology, it is suffice to prove that for all a∈Xa \in Xa∈X and ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 there exists {aα}\{a_{\alpha}\}{aα​} and {ϵα}\{\epsilon_{\alpha}\}{ϵα​} where ϵα≤1\epsilon_{\alpha} \leq 1ϵα​≤1 such that Bd(a,ϵ)=⋃Bd‾(aα,ϵα)B_{d}(a,\epsilon) = \bigcup B_{\overline{d}}(a_{\alpha},\epsilon_{\alpha})Bd​(a,ϵ)=⋃Bd​(aα​,ϵα​)

For every x∈Bd(a,ϵ)x \in B_{d}(a,\epsilon)x∈Bd​(a,ϵ) take ax=xa_{x} = xax​=x and ϵx<min(ϵ−d(a,x),1)\epsilon_{x} < min(\epsilon - d(a,x),1)ϵx​<min(ϵ−d(a,x),1) . Then Bd(a,ϵ)⊇Bd‾(ax,ϵx)B_{d}(a,\epsilon) \supseteq B_{\overline{d}}(a_{x},\epsilon_{x})Bd​(a,ϵ)⊇Bd​(ax​,ϵx​) as for all y∈Bd‾(ax,ϵx)y \in B_{\overline{d}}(a_{x},\epsilon_{x})y∈Bd​(ax​,ϵx​)

d(a,y)≤d(a,ax)+d(ax,y)<min(ϵ−d(a,x),1)+d(a,ax)≤ϵ\begin{aligned} d(a,y) &\leq& d(a,a_{x}) + d(a_{x},y) \\ &<& min(\epsilon - d(a,x),1) + d(a,a_{x}) \\ &\leq& \epsilon \end{aligned}d(a,y)​≤<≤​d(a,ax​)+d(ax​,y)min(ϵ−d(a,x),1)+d(a,ax​)ϵ​

Thus Bd(a,ϵ)=⋃x∈Bd(a,ϵ)Bd‾(ax,ϵx)B_{d}(a,\epsilon) = \bigcup_{ x \in B_{d}(a,\epsilon) } B_{\overline{d}}(a_{x},\epsilon_{x})Bd​(a,ϵ)=⋃x∈Bd​(a,ϵ)​Bd​(ax​,ϵx​) ◻ :::

::: {#def:Norm .definition} Definition 1.47 (norm). *Given x=(x1,…,xn)x = (x_{1},\dots,x_{n})x=(x1​,…,xn​) in Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn . The norm of xxx is defined by the equation

∣∣x∣∣=(x12+⋯+xn2)12||x|| = ( x_{1}^{2}+\dots+x_{n}^{2} )^{\frac{1}{2}}∣∣x∣∣=(x12​+⋯+xn2​)21​

:::

::: {#def:EuclideanMetric .definition} Definition 1.48 (euclidean metric). The euclidean metric ddd on Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is defined by d(x,y)=∣∣x−y∣∣d(x,y) = ||x-y||d(x,y)=∣∣x−y∣∣ :::

::: {#def:SquareMetric .definition} Definition 1.49 (square metric). The square metric ρ\rhoρ on Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn is defined by ρ(x,y)=max{∣x1−y1∣,…,∣xn−yn∣}\rho(x,y) = max\{ |x_{1}-y_{1}|,\dots,|x_{n}-y_{n}| \}ρ(x,y)=max{∣x1​−y1​∣,…,∣xn​−yn​∣} :::

::: lemma Lemma 1.8. Let ddd and d′d'd′ be two metrics on the set X\mathbb{X}X ; let T\mathbb{T}T and T′\mathbb{T'}T′ be the topology induced by ddd and d′d'd′ respectively. Then T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is finer than TTT if and only if for all x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X and ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 , there exists a δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that Bd′(x,δ)⊆Bd(x,ϵ)B_{d'}(x,\delta) \subseteq B_{d}(x,\epsilon)Bd′​(x,δ)⊆Bd​(x,ϵ) :::

::: proof Proof. If T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is finer than T\mathbb{T}T . Then for all Bd(x,ϵ)B_{d}(x,\epsilon)Bd​(x,ϵ) there exists a open set UUU that containing xxx such that U⊆Bd(x,ϵ)U \subseteq B_{d}(x,\epsilon)U⊆Bd​(x,ϵ) . As {Bd′(x,δ)}\{{B_{d'}(x,\delta)}\}{Bd′​(x,δ)} is a basis of T′T'T′ , then there exists Bd′(x,δ)⊆UB_{d'}(x,\delta) \subseteq UBd′​(x,δ)⊆U that containing xxx .

If for all Bd(x,ϵ)B_{d}(x,\epsilon)Bd​(x,ϵ) , there exists Bd′(x,δ)⊆Bd(x,ϵ)B_{d'}(x,\delta) \subseteq B_{d}(x,\epsilon)Bd′​(x,δ)⊆Bd​(x,ϵ) . Then as {Bd′(x,ϵ)}\{{B_{d'}(x,\epsilon)}\}{Bd′​(x,ϵ)} and {Bd(x,ϵ)}\{{B_{d}(x,\epsilon)}\}{Bd​(x,ϵ)} are both basis, then T′\mathbb{T'}T′ is finer than TTT . ◻ :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.28. 49 The topologies on Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn induced by the euclidean metric ddd and the square metric ρ\rhoρ are the same as the product topology on Rn\mathbb{R}^{n}Rn . :::

::: {#def:UniformMetric .definition} Definition 1.50 (uniform metric, uniform topology). *Given an index set JJJ , and given points x=(xα)α∈Jx = (x_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in J}x=(xα​)α∈J​ and y=(yα)α∈Jy = (y_{\alpha})_{\alpha \in J}y=(yα​)α∈J​ of RJ\mathbb{R}^{J}RJ , let us define a metric ρ‾\overline{\rho}ρ​ on RJ\mathbb{R}^{J}RJ by the equation

ρ‾(x,y)=sup⁡{d‾(xα,yα)∣α∈J}\overline{\rho}(x,y) = \sup\{ \overline{d}(x_{\alpha},y_{\alpha}) | \alpha \in J \}ρ​(x,y)=sup{d(xα​,yα​)∣α∈J}

where d‾\overline{d}d is the standard bounded metric on R\mathbb{R}R . ρ‾\overline{\rho}ρ​ is called the uniform metric on RJ\mathbb{R}^{J}RJ , and the topology it induces is called the uniform topology* :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.29. 50 The uniform topology on RJ\mathbb{R}^{J}RJ is finer than the product topology and is coarser than the box topology. :::

::: theorem Theorem 1.30. *Let d‾(a,b)=min⁡{∣a−b∣,1}\overline{d}(a,b) = \min\{ |a-b|,1 \}d(a,b)=min{∣a−b∣,1} be the standard bounded metric on R\mathbb{R}R . If xxx nad yyy are two points of Rω\mathbb{R}^{\omega}Rω , define

D(x,y)=sup⁡{d‾(xi,yi)i}D(x,y) = \sup\left\{ \frac{\overline{d}(x_{i},y_{i})}{i} \right\}D(x,y)=sup{id(xi​,yi​)​}

Then DDD is a metric that induces the product topology on Rω\mathbb{R}^{\omega}Rω :::

::: proof Proof. The properties of a metric are satisfied trivially except for the triangle inequality, which is proved by noting that for all iii ,

d‾(xi,zi)i≤d‾(xi,yi)i+d‾(yi,zi)i≤D(x,y)+D(y,z)\begin{aligned} \frac{\overline{d}(x_{i},z_{i})}{i} &\le& \frac{\overline{d}(x_{i},y_{i})}{i} + \frac{\overline{d}(y_{i},z_{i})}{i} \\ &\le& D(x,y) + D(y,z) \end{aligned}id(xi​,zi​)​​≤≤​id(xi​,yi​)​+id(yi​,zi​)​D(x,y)+D(y,z)​

so that

sup⁡{d‾(xi,zi)i}≤D(x,y)+D(y,z)\sup\left\{ \frac{\overline{d}(x_{i},z_{i})}{i} \right\} \le D(x,y) + D(y,z)sup{id(xi​,zi​)​}≤D(x,y)+D(y,z)

The fact that DDD gives the product topology requires a little more work. First, let UUU be open in the metric topology and let x∈Ux \in Ux∈U ; we find an open set VVV in the product topology such that x∈V⊇Ux \in V \supseteq Ux∈V⊇U . Choose an ϵ−ball\epsilon-ballϵ−ball BD(x,ϵ)B_{D}(x,\epsilon)BD​(x,ϵ) lying in UUU . Then choose NNN large enough that 1N<ϵ\frac{1}{N} < \epsilonN1​<ϵ . Finally, let VVV be the basis element for the product topology V=(x1−ϵ,x1+ϵ)×⋯×(xN−ϵ,xN+ϵ)×R×R×…V = (x_{1}-\epsilon,x_{1}+\epsilon) \times \dots \times (x_{N}-\epsilon,x_{N}+\epsilon) \times R \times R \times \dotsV=(x1​−ϵ,x1​+ϵ)×⋯×(xN​−ϵ,xN​+ϵ)×R×R×…

::: theorem Theorem 1.31. Let f:X→Yf: \mathbf{X} \rightarrow \mathbf{Y}f:X→Y be metrizable with metric dXd_{\mathbf{X}}dX​ and dYd_{\mathbf{Y}}dY​ , respectively. Then continuity of fff is equivalent to the requirement that given x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X and given ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 , there exists δ>0\delta > 0δ>0 such that dX(x,y)<δ  ⟹  dY(f(x),f(y))<ϵd_{\mathbf{X}}(x,y) < \delta \implies d_{\mathbb{Y}}(f(x),f(y)) < \epsilondX​(x,y)<δ⟹dY​(f(x),f(y))<ϵ :::

::: proof Proof. Suppose fff is continuous. Given xxx and ϵ\epsilonϵ , consider the set f−1(B(f(x),ϵ))f^{-1}(B(f(x),\epsilon))f−1(B(f(x),ϵ)) which is open in X\mathbb{X}X and contains the point xxx . It contains some δ\deltaδ -ball B(x,δ)B(x,\delta)B(x,δ) centered at xxx . If yyy is in this δ\deltaδ -ball, then f(y)f(y)f(y) is in this δ\deltaδ -ball as desired.

Conversely, suppose that the ϵ−δ\epsilon-\deltaϵ−δ condition is satisfied. Let VVV be open in Y\mathbb{Y}Y ; we show that f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) is open in X\mathbb{X}X . Let xxx be a point of the set f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) . Since f(x)∈Vf(x) \in Vf(x)∈V there is an ϵ\epsilonϵ -ball B(f(x),ϵ)B(f(x),\epsilon)B(f(x),ϵ) centered at f(x)f(x)f(x) and contained in VVV . By the ϵ−δ\epsilon-\deltaϵ−δ condition, there exists a δ\deltaδ -ball centered at xxx such that f(B(x,δ))⊆B(f(x),ϵ)f(B(x,\delta)) \subseteq B(f(x),\epsilon)f(B(x,δ))⊆B(f(x),ϵ) . Then B(x,δ)B(x,\delta)B(x,δ) is a neighbourhood of xxx contained in f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) , so that f−1(V)f^{-1}(V)f−1(V) is open, as desired. ◻ :::

::: {#def:ConvergeUniformly .definition} Definition 1.54 (converge uniformly). Let fn:X→Yf_{n}: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}fn​:X→Y be a sequence of functions from the set X\mathbb{X}X to the metric space Y\mathbb{Y}Y . Let ddd be the metric for Y\mathbb{Y}Y . We say that the sequence (fn)(f_{n})(fn​) converges uniformly to the function f:X→Yf : \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y if given ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 , there exists an integer NNN such that d(fn(x),f(x))<ϵd(f_{n}(x),f(x)) < \epsilond(fn​(x),f(x))<ϵ for all n>Nn > Nn>N and all x∈Xx \in \mathbb{X}x∈X :::

::: {#def:UniformLimitTheorem .theorem} Theorem 1.34 (Uniform limit theorem). Let fn:X→Yf_{n} : \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}fn​:X→Y be a sequence of continuous functions from the topological space X\mathbb{X}X to the metric space Y\mathbb{Y}Y . If (fn)(f_{n})(fn​) converges uniformly to fff , then fff is continuous. :::

::: {#def:IsometricImbedding .definition} Definition 1.55 (isometric imbedding). Let X\mathbb{X}X and Y\mathbb{Y}Y be metric spaces with metric dXd_{\mathbb{X}}dX​ and dYd_{\mathbb{Y}}dY​ , respectively. Let f:X→Yf: \mathbb{X} \rightarrow \mathbb{Y}f:X→Y have the property that for every pair of points x1x_{1}x1​ , x2x_{2}x2​ of X\mathbb{X}X , and dY(f(x1),f(x2))=dX(x1,x2)d_{\mathbb{Y}}(f(x_{1}),f(x_{2})) = d_{\mathbb{X}}(x_{1},x_{2})dY​(f(x1​),f(x2​))=dX​(x1​,x2​)

fff is an topological imbedding and is called an isometric imbedding of X\mathbb{X}X in Y\mathbb{Y}Y :::
